{{pp-semi-blp|expiry=September 11, 2012|small=yes}} {{Infobox person |name = Matt Damon |image = Damon cropped.jpg |image_size = |alt = Head shot of Damon looking into the camera smiling slightly. He is wearing a black polo shirt. |caption = Damon in 2009 |birth_name = Matthew Paige Damon |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1970|10|08|mf=yes}} |birth_place = [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. |alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] <small>(Dropped out)</small> |occupation = Actor, screenwriter, producer |years_active = 1988âpresent |spouse = Luciana Barroso <small>(m. 2005–present)</small> |children = 4 |awards = [[Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay|Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay]], [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay]] }} '''Matthew Paige''' "'''Matt'''" '''Damon''' (born October 8, 1970) is an American actor, screenwriter, and [[philanthropist]] whose career was launched following the success of the film ''[[Good Will Hunting]]'' (1997), from a screenplay he co-wrote with friend [[Ben Affleck]]. The pair won the [[Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay|Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay]] and the [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay]] for their work and Damon received multiple Best Actor nominations, including the [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Academy Award]], for his lead performance in the film.
Damon has since starred in commercially successful films such as ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]'' (1998), the [[Ocean's Trilogy|''Ocean's'' trilogy]], and the [[Bourne (film series)|''Bourne'' series]], while also gaining critical acclaim for his performances in dramas such as ''[[Syriana]]'' (2005), ''[[The Good Shepherd (film)|The Good Shepherd]]'' (2006), and ''[[The Departed]]'' (2006). He garnered a Golden Globe nomination for portraying the title character in ''[[The Talented Mr. Ripley (film)|The Talented Mr. Ripley]]'' (1999) and was nominated for an Academy Award as a supporting actor in ''[[Invictus (film)|Invictus]]'' (2009). He is one of the top forty highest grossing actors of all time. In 2007, Damon received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] and was named [[Sexiest Man Alive]] by ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine.
Damon has been actively involved in charitable work, including the [[ONE Campaign]], [[H2O Africa Foundation]], and [[Water.org]].
== Early life == Matt Damon was born in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], [[Massachusetts]], the son of Kent Telfer Damon, a [[stockbroker]], and Nancy Carlsson-Paige, an [[early childhood education]] professor at [[Lesley University]].<ref name="KentReal">{{cite news|last=Luscombe|first=Belinda|publisher=''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''|title=Matt Damon Acts Out|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,36294-1,00.html|date=December 19, 1999|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref><ref name="LiveCambridge">{{cite news|last=Givens|first=Ron|coauthors=Michele McPhee|publisher=''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]''|title=Two Hollywood Prizefighters 'Hunting' for Stardom Pays Off for Matt Damon|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1998/03/22/1998-03-22_two_hollywood_prizefighters_.html|date=March 22, 1998|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> Damon is of [[Scottish American|Scottish]], [[English American|English]], [[Finnish American|Finnish]], and [[Swedish American|Swedish]]<!--Please stop removing "Swedish", it is supported by references.--> ancestry, and is a distant cousin of actors [[Ben Affleck]] and [[Casey Affleck]].<ref name="newengland">{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Genealogical Chart Knowlton Line of Ben Affleck and Matt Damon|publisher=[[New England Historic Genealogical Society]]|year=2009|url=http://www.newenglandancestors.org/pdfs/affleck_damon_connection.pdf|format=|accessdate=2010-02-02}}</ref><ref name="wargs1">{{cite web|last=|first=|authorlink=|coauthors=|title=Matt Damon|publisher=Rootsweb|date=|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/celeb/damon.htm|accessdate=2010-02-02}}</ref> He has a brother, Kyle, who is an accomplished [[sculptor]] and artist.<ref name="LiveCambridge"/><ref name="Animation">{{cite news|last=Ball|first=Ryan|publisher=''[[Animation Magazine]]''|title=Matt Damon Animated for Arthur|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/article/7229|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> He and his family moved to [[Newton, Massachusetts|Newton]] and lived there for two years. After his parents divorced, Damon and his brother moved with their mother back to Cambridge,<ref name="LiveCambridge"/><ref name="ParentsDivorce">{{cite news|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|title=Matt Damon: A true Hollywood player|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/matt-damon-a-true-hollywood-player-418808.html|date=October 4, 2006|accessdate=April 5, 2009 | location=London}}</ref> where they lived in a six-family communal house.<ref name="ParadeProfile03">{{cite news|last=Raider|first=Dotson|publisher=''[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]''|title="My Goals Have Changed" (Actor Matt Damon)|url=http://www.parade.com/articles/editions/2003/edition_11-30-2003/featured_0|date=November 30, 2003|accessdate=April 21, 2010}}</ref><ref name="NeutralNarrate">{{cite news|last=Crust|first=Kevin|publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|title='Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train,' 'Hair Show,' 'The Hillside Strangler,' 'The Dust Factory' and 'Stephen King's Riding the Bullet'|url=http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/reviews/cl-et-capsules15oct15,2,1749015.story|date=October 15, 2004|accessdate=April 5, 2009|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080604162332/http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/reviews/cl-et-capsules15oct15,2,1749015.story |archivedate = June 4, 2008|deadurl=yes}}</ref> Damon grew up near Ben Affleck, a close friend since childhood and collaborator on several films, and [[historian]] and author [[Howard Zinn]],<ref name="UnholyAlliance">{{cite book|last=Horowitz|first=David|title=Unholy Alliance: Radical Islam And The American Left|publisher=Regnery Publishing|year=2004|location=|page=102|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=azE5qoXTgoAC&pg=PA102&lpg=PA102&dq=matt+damon+howard+zinn+neighbor&source=web&ots=L-uGfPq5A5&sig=NaQBpDX55Gn7hFB_DEn2i2cSepY#PPA102,M1|isbn=089526076X|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> whose biographical film ''You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train'' and audio version of ''[[A People's History of the United States]]'' Damon later narrated.<ref name="NeutralNarrate"/>
Damon took to [[role-playing]] as a child partly because his mother raised him "by the book,"<ref name="ParadeProfile03"/> which made him feel as though "you couldnât define yourself, because you already had been defined by her."<ref name="ParadeProfile03"/> He attended Cambridge Alternative School (now Graham & Parks) and then [[Cambridge Rindge and Latin School]], where he was a disciplined student<ref name="WTprofile97"/> but had a "terrifying" first two years due to his short height at the time.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|title=Ripley Believe It or Not|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,272093_2,00.html|date=December 17, 1999|accessdate=April 23, 2010}}</ref> As a lonely adolescent, Damon has described feeling "such pain in wanting to belong somewhere and not belonging."<ref name="ParadeProfile03"/> Damon performed as an actor in several high school theater productions;<ref name="LiveCambridge"/> he has credited his drama teacher at Rindge and Latin, Gerry Speca, as an important artistic influence, even though Damon recalls that, "Mr. Speca always seemed to trust Ben [Affleck] with the biggest roles and longest speeches."<ref name="WTprofile97">{{cite news|last=Arnold|first=Gary|publisher=''[[The Washington Times]]''|title=Boyhood friends are stars on the rise|url=|date=December 26, 1997|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref>
Damon attended [[Harvard University]] from 1988 to 1992 but did not graduate.<ref name="Harvard1992">{{cite news|last=McGrath|first=Charles|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|title=6 Degrees of Harvard|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/01/weekinreview/01mcgrath.html?scp=1&sq=matt%20damon%20harvard%201992&st=cse|date=October 1, 2006|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> While at Harvard, he studied English and lived in [[Lowell House]]. He took part in student theater,<ref>{{cite web|last=Chainani|first=Soman|publisher=''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''|title=Matt Damon On Life, Acting and Harvard|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article/1997/12/12/matt-damon-on-life-acting-and/|accessdate=April 21, 2010}}</ref> appearing in plays such as ''Burn This in Winthrop House'' and ''A... My Name is Alice'' (in one of the three male roles usually performed by women).<ref name="HarvardCrimson">{{cite news|last=Siegler|first=Elijah|publisher=''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''|title=Ex Show Safe but Satisfying|url=http://www.thecrimson.com/article.aspx?ref=266489|date=November 2, 1990|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> Damon dropped out of the university to pursue his acting career in Los Angeles because he mistakenly expected ''[[Geronimo: An American Legend]]'' to become a big success.<ref name="TisCaliBio">{{cite web|last=Wills|first=Dominic|publisher=[[Tiscali|Tiscali.ca]]|title=Matt Damon Biography|url=http://www.tiscali.co.uk/entertainment/film/biographies/matt_damon_biog.html|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> "By the time I figured out I had made the wrong decision, it was too late. I was living out here with a bunch of actors, and we were all scrambling to make ends meet," Damon has said.<ref>{{cite news|last=Koltnow|first=Barry |publisher=''The Orange County Register ''|title=Looking for Mr. 'Good' Guy|date=December 5, 1999|accessdate=April 21, 2010}}</ref>
== Acting career == === Early years === Damon's first film role came in 1988 when he was eighteen, with a single line of dialogue in the romantic comedy ''[[Mystic Pizza]]''.<ref name="People - Bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/matt_damon/biography|title=Matt Damon Biography|accessdate=April 5, 2009|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]}}</ref> As a student at Harvard University, he continued to pursue acting and performed small roles in projects such as the [[Turner Network Television|TNT]] original film ''Rising Son'' and the ensemble prep-school drama ''[[School Ties]]''.<ref name="actors">Stated in interview on ''[[Inside the Actors Studio]]''</ref> In 1992, he landed a big part in ''[[Geronimo: An American Legend]]'' with [[Gene Hackman]] and [[Jason Patric]].<ref name="actors"/> Four years later, he auditioned for a small role in ''[[Cutthroat Island]]'', but was turned away.<ref name="InterCutthroat">{{cite news|last=Johnston|first=Sheila|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|title=Interview: Matt Damon: The talented Mr Damon tries on the Emperor's new clothes for size|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/interview-matt-damon-the-talented-mr-damon-tries-on-the-emperors-new-clothes-for-size-1183460.html|date=November 8, 1998|accessdate=April 5, 2009 | location=London}}</ref> Damon next appeared as an [[opiate]]-addicted soldier in 1996's ''[[Courage Under Fire]]''. He was required to lose {{convert|40|lb|kg}} in 100 days (for only two days of filming).<ref name="EW40lbs">{{cite news|last=Greenblatt|first=Leah|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|title=Actorexia: A Brief History|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20057925,00.html|date=September 21, 2007|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref><ref name="YahooIndia">{{cite web|author=ANI|publisher=YahooIndia|title=Weight loss left Damon feeling like a "wreck"|url=http://in.movies.yahoo.com/news-detail/4666/Weight-loss-left-Damon-feeling-like-wreck.html|date=August 4, 2007|accessdate=April 5, 2009|authorlink=Asian News International}}</ref> After following a self-prescribed diet and fitness regimen to lose the weight, Damon was told after filming that he was fortunate his heart did not shrink. He took medication for several years afterwards to correct the stress inflicted on his [[adrenal gland]]. ''Courage Under Fire'' gained him some critical notice, as ''[[The Washington Post]]'' labeled his performance "impressive;"<ref>{{cite news|last=Kempley|first=Rita|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|title=Hand-to-Heart Combat |url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/longterm/review96/courageunderfirekemp.htm|date=November 8, 1998|accessdate=April 21, 2010}}</ref> Damon has stated that it was worthwhile to risk his health in order to properly portray his character and show the industry how committed he was to his work as an actor.<ref name="People - Bio"/><ref name="YahooIndia"/>
=== Breakthrough === During the early 1990s, Damon and Affleck wrote a screenplay about a young math genius, which they then pitched around Hollywood for a long time. Receiving advice from director [[Rob Reiner]], screenwriter [[William Goldman]], and their friend writer/director [[Kevin Smith]], the two made changes to the script.<ref name="TisCaliBio"/> The script eventually became ''[[Good Will Hunting]]'' (1997), and received nine [[Academy Awards]] nominations, earning Damon and Affleck [[Academy Awards|Oscars]] for [[Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]].<ref name="Hartford9Nominations">{{cite news|last=Wallace|first=Amy|coauthors=Robert W. Welkos and Susan King|title='Titanic' Ties Record for Oscar Nominations|publisher=''[[The Hartford Courant]]''|url=http://www.courant.com/topic/cl-env-1998oscarnoms,0,2173092.story?page=1|date=February 11, 1998|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref><ref name="WashPostWin">{{cite news|last=Waxman|first=Sharon|coauthors=William Booth|title='Titanic's' 11 Oscars Ties Record; Night 'Good' for Nicholson, Hunt|publisher=''[[The Washington Post]]''|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/style/movies/oscars/oscars98.htm|date=March 23, 1998|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> Damon was also nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] for the same film, which also netted an [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Oscar for Best Supporting Actor]] for co-star [[Robin Williams]].<ref name="Hartford9Nominations"/> He and Affleck were each paid salaries of $600,000, while the film grossed over $225 million at the worldwide box office.<ref name="bomojo"/><ref name="BioChannel$500K">{{cite web|publisher=[[The Biography Channel]]|title=Matt Damon|url=http://www.thebiographychannel.co.uk/biography_story/1685:2046/1/Matt_Damon.htm|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> The two later parodied their roles from the film in Kevin Smith's 2001 movie ''[[Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back]]''.
Also in 1997, Damon was the lead in the critically acclaimed drama ''[[The Rainmaker (1997 film)|The Rainmaker]]'', where he was recognized by the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' as "a talented young actor on the brink of stardom."<ref>{{cite web|first=Jack|last=Matthews|url=http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/reviews/cl-movie980106-50,0,962161.story|title=John Grisham's The Rainmaker|accessdate=April 21, 2010|date=November 21, 1997|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5qpFLz7Bh|archivedate=June 28, 2010}}</ref> After meeting Damon on the set of ''Good Will Hunting'', director [[Steven Spielberg]] cast Damon as the titular character in the 1998 [[World War II]] film ''[[Saving Private Ryan]]''.<ref name="TisCaliBio"/>
=== Hollywood star === [[File:Ocean's11Cast.jpg|alt=Six actors, all but one wearing a leather jacket, are photographed on a stage with a blue curtain as a backdrop.|thumb|right|[[Brad Pitt]], [[George Clooney]], Damon, [[Andy GarcÃ­a]], [[Julia Roberts]] (the cast of ''[[Ocean's Eleven (2001 film)|Ocean's Eleven]]''), with director [[Steven Soderbergh]] in December 2001]] Damon has become known for choosing a wide variety of film roles,<ref name="NYT06"/> from his portrayal of [[Patricia Highsmith]]'s anti-hero [[Tom Ripley]] in ''[[The Talented Mr. Ripley (film)|The Talented Mr. Ripley]]'' (1999)<ref name="People - Bio"/> to a [[fallen angel]] who discusses [[pop culture]] as intellectual subject matter with Affleck in ''[[Dogma (film)|Dogma]]'' (1999); from a [[conjoined twin]] in ''[[Stuck on You (film)|Stuck on You]]'' (2003), which got a mixed critical reception,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/stuck_on_you/|title=Stuck on You reviews|accessdate=April 21, 2010|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}</ref> to the low budget experimental film ''[[Gerry (2002 film)|Gerry]]'' (2002), which he co-wrote with [[Casey Affleck]] and [[Gus Van Sant]]. Damon garnered generally positive critical reaction for his [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe]]-nominated<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/browse/member/29686|title=HFPA â Awards Search|accessdate=April 5, 2009|publisher=[[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]]}}</ref> portrayal of Ripley, with ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' stating, "Damon outstandingly conveys his character's slide from innocent enthusiasm into cold calculation."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117759854.html?categoryid=31&cs=1|title=The Talented Mr. Ripley â film review|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | first=Todd | last=McCarthy | date=December 13, 1999}}</ref>
Damon's attempts at essaying leading characters in romantic dramas such as 2000's ''[[All the Pretty Horses (film)|All the Pretty Horses]]'' and ''[[The Legend of Bagger Vance]]'' were commercially and critically unsuccessful.<ref name="bomojo"/> ''Variety'' said of his work in ''All the Pretty Horses'': "[Damon] just doesn't quite seem like a young man who's spent his life amidst the dust and dung of a Texas cattle ranch. Nor does he strike any sparks with [Penelope] Cruz."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117796963.html?categoryid=31&cs=1|title=All the Pretty Horses â film review|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | first=Todd | last=McCarthy | date=December 13, 2000}}</ref> He was similarly deemed "uncomfortable being the center" of [[Robert Redford]]'s ''The Legend of Bagger Vance''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/movies/reviews/4029/|title=The Legend of Bagger Vance â film review|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]}}</ref>
From 2001 to 2007, Damon gained wider international recognition as part of two major film franchises. He co-starred as thief Linus Caldwell, alongside [[George Clooney]], [[Brad Pitt]], and [[Julia Roberts]], in [[Steven Soderbergh]]'s 2001 [[Ocean's Eleven (2001 film)|remake]] of the [[Rat Pack]]'s 1960 caper film ''[[Ocean's 11 (1960 film)|Ocean's 11]]''; the successful crime [[dramedy]] spawned two sequels, ''[[Ocean's Twelve]]'' (2004) and ''[[Ocean's Thirteen]]'' (2007).<ref name="People - Bio"/> He played [[amnesia]]c assassin [[Jason Bourne (character)|Jason Bourne]] in the hit action thrillers ''[[The Bourne Identity (2002 film)|The Bourne Identity]]'' (2002), ''[[The Bourne Supremacy (film)|The Bourne Supremacy]]'' (2004), and ''[[The Bourne Ultimatum (film)|The Bourne Ultimatum]]'' (2007).<ref name="People - Bio"/> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' placed Damon as an "action star" on its end-of-the-decade, "best-of" list, saying, "When he first signed on as the ass-kicking amnesiac Jason Bourne in 2002, no one would've predicted that Damon would become the decade's best mixer of brawn and brains. Shows what we know."<ref>{{cite journal|first=Thom|last=Geier|coauthors=Jeff Jensen, Tina Jordan, Margaret Lyons, Adam Markovitz, Chris Nashawaty, Whitney Pastorek, Lynette Rice, Josh Rottenberg, Missy Schwartz, Michael Slezak, Dan Snierson, Tim Stack, Kate Stroup, Ken Tucker, Adam B. Vary, Simon Vozick-Levinson, Kate Ward|date=2009-12-11|title=The 100 Greatest Movies, TV Shows, Albums, Books, Characters, Scenes, Episodes, Songs, Dresses, Music Videos, And Trends That Entertained Us Over The Past 10 Years|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|page=(1079/1080):74â84}}</ref> In August 2007, financial magazine ''[[Forbes]]'' created a list of actors who generated the best box office performance related to their salaries; the list placed Damon as the most bankable star of the actors reviewed, revealing that Damon had averaged USD29 at the box office for every [[dollar]] he earned for his last three films.<ref name="ForbesPayback">{{cite news|last=Pomerantz|first=Dorothy|work=[[Forbes]]|title=Ultimate Star Payback|url=http://www.forbes.com/2007/08/03/celebrities-hollywood-movies-biz-cz_dp_0806starpayback.html|date=August 6, 2007|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref><ref name="BOBanker">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/a-boxoffice-banker-how-matt-damon-became-hollywoods-leading-man-460666.html|title=A box-office banker: How Matt Damon became Hollywood's leading man|accessdate=April 5, 2009|date=August 8, 2007|work=[[The Independent]] | location=London}}</ref>
[[File:RobertDeNiroMattDamonBerlinFeb07.jpg|alt= Photo of Damon and De Niro, each wearing a tuxedo jacket and a dark blue shirt.|thumb|right|Damon with [[Robert De Niro]] in Berlin in February 2007 for the premiere of ''[[The Good Shepherd (film)|The Good Shepherd]]'']] Damon played a fictionalized version of [[Wilhelm Grimm]] in [[Terry Gilliam]]'s fantasy adventure ''[[The Brothers Grimm (film)|The Brothers Grimm]]'' (2005), which was a critically panned commercial failure;<ref name="bomojo"/> ''[[The Washington Post]]'' concluded, "Damon, constantly flashing his newscaster's teeth and flaunting a fake, 'Masterpiece Theatre' dialect, comes across like someone who got lost on the way to an audition for a high school production of 'The Pirates of Penzance.'"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/08/25/AR2005082500539.html|title=A Disappointingly 'Grimm' Tale|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[The Washington Post]] | first=Michael | last=O'Sullivan | date=August 26, 2005}}</ref> Later that year, he appeared as an [[Energy analysis|energy analyst]] in ''[[Syriana]]''.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lisa|last=Schwarzbaum|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/SHOWBIZ/Movies/11/23/ew.mov.syriana/index.html?iref=newssearch|title=EW review: 'Syriana' lacks humanity|accessdate=April 5, 2009|date=November 23, 2005|publisher=CNN}}</ref> In 2006, Damon joined [[Robert De Niro]] in ''[[The Good Shepherd (film)|The Good Shepherd]]'' as a career [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] officer, and played an undercover [[mobster]] working for the [[Massachusetts State Police]] in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s ''[[The Departed]]'', a remake of the [[Hong Kong]] police thriller ''[[Infernal Affairs]]''.<ref name="People - Bio"/> Assessing his work in the two films, [[Manohla Dargis]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote that Damon "does what few stars with his kind of billing do: he disappears."<ref name="NYT06">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/10/movies/moviesspecial/10darg.html|title=The Boyish Mr. Damon, Not So Boyish After All|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[The New York Times]] | first=Manohla | last=Dargis | date=September 10, 2006}}</ref> ''The Departed'' was a success amongst critics and audiences alike.<ref name="bomojo">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Actor&id=mattdamon.htm|title=Box Office Mojo â Matt Damon|accessdate=April 21, 2010|publisher=Box Office Mojo}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/departed/|title=The Departed reviews|accessdate=April 21, 2010|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}</ref>
Damon had an uncredited cameo in [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s '' [[Youth Without Youth (film)|Youth Without Youth]]'' (2007) and another cameo in the 2008 [[Che Guevara]] biopic ''[[Che (film)|Che]]''. He lent his voice to the [[English language|English]] version of the animated film ''[[Ponyo on the Cliff by the Sea]]'', which was released in the United States in August 2009.<ref name="PonyoVoice">{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/film/2008/nov/27/hayaomiyazaki|title=English-language cast announced for Miyazaki's Ponyo on the Cliff|publisher=[[guardian.co.uk]]|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=April 5, 2009|date=November 27, 2008 | location=London}}</ref> He also made a guest appearance in 2009 on the sixth season finale of ''[[Entourage (TV series)|Entourage]]'' as himself, where he tries to pressure [[Vincent Chase]] ([[Adrian Grenier]]) into donating to his charity OneXOneâa real foundation for which Damon is an ambassadorâand gets increasingly irritated when Chase does not seem to comply.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20290886,00.html|title=Matt Damon Fundraises on ''Entourage''|last=Silverman|first=Stephen M.|date=July 13, 2009|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=November 5, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bostonherald.com/track/inside_track/view.bg?articleid=1203803&srvc=home&position=also|title=We Hear: Tom Werner, Katy Davis, Matt Damon & more...|date=October 11, 2009|work=[[Boston Herald]]|accessdate=November 5, 2009}}</ref>
Damon next appeared in Steven Soderbergh's dark comedy, ''[[The Informant!]]'' (2009),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1924598,00.html|title=''The Informant!'' Matt Damon's Weighty Comedy|last=Corliss|first=Richard|date=September 17, 2009|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|accessdate=November 5, 2009}}</ref> in which his Golden Globe-nominated work was described by ''Entertainment Weekly'' as such: "The star â who has quietly and steadily turned into a great Everyman actor â is in nimble control as he reveals his character's deep crazies."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20304807,00.html|title=The Informant|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref> Also in 2009, Damon portrayed [[South Africa national rugby union team]] captain [[Francois Pienaar|FranÃ§ois Pienaar]] in the [[Clint Eastwood]]-directed [[Nelson Mandela]] film ''[[Invictus (film)|Invictus]]'', which is based on the 2008 [[John Carlin]] book ''Playing the Enemy: Nelson Mandela and the Game That Changed a Nation'' and features [[Morgan Freeman]] as Mandela.<ref name="HumanFactor">{{cite news|last=Leys|first=Nick|url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,25187212-5006010,00.html|title= Matt Damon takes rugby union to Hollywood|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=April 5, 2009|date=March 15, 2009}}</ref> ''Invictus'' earned Damon an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor. ''[[The New Republic]]'' observed, "It is not a demanding role, but the ever-more-actorly Damon brings it off with low-key charm and integrity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tnr.com/blog/the-plank/the-mini-review-invictus|title=The Mini-Review: 'Invictus'|accessdate=April 21, 2010|work=[[The New Republic]]}}</ref>
[[File:MattDamonGraumanHandFootprintsOct10.jpg|alt=Hand and foot prints in cement dated of June 6, 2007|thumb|Handprints and footprints of Damon in front of the [[Grauman's Chinese Theatre]]]] In 2010, Damon re-teamed with director Paul Greengrass, who directed him in the ''Bourne Supremacy'' and ''Bourne Ultimatum'', for the action thriller ''[[Green Zone (film)|Green Zone]]'', which flopped commercially<ref name=corliss>{{cite news|last=Corliss|first=Richard|title=Alice turns Damon a sickly Green|url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1971941,00.html|date=March 14, 2010|accessdate=April 16, 2010|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref> and received ambivalent reception from critics.<ref name="green zone reviews">{{cite web|url=http://au.rottentomatoes.com/m/1202804-green_zone/ |title=Green Zone Movie Reviews |publisher=[[IGN Entertainment]] |work=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=April 12, 2010}}</ref>
In motion pictures that feature him either as a leading actor or as a supporting co-star, his films have grossed a total of U.S.$1.94<ref name="BOMlist">{{cite web|publisher=Box Office Mojo|title=Actors #1â50|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/?view=Actor&sort=sumgross&p=.htm|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> to U.S.$2.42 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]]<ref name="The Numbers">{{cite web|publisher=The Numbers|title=All Time Top 100 Stars at the Box Office|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/people/records/| accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> (based on counting his roles as strictly lead or including supporting roles, respectively) at the North American box office, placing him in the top forty grossing actors of all time.
He has appeared as a guest star in an episode of ''[[Arthur (TV series)|Arthur]]'', titled ''The Making of Arthur'', as himself.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/article/7229|title=Matt Damon Animated for Arthur}}</ref> During Season 5 of ''[[30 Rock]]'', he appeared as guest star in the role of [[Liz Lemon]]'s boyfriend in the episodes "I Do I Do," "The Fabian Strategy," "[[Live Show]]," and "Double Edged Sword."
Damon's 2010 projects included ''[[The Adjustment Bureau]]'', Clint Eastwood's ''[[Hereafter (film)|Hereafter]]'', and the [[Coen Brothers]]' remake of the [[True Grit (1969 film)|1969 John Wayne-starring]] Western ''[[True Grit (2010 film)|True Grit]]''; the latter movie started filming in March 2010 and was released in December of that year.<ref name="collider 2010 interview">{{cite web |title=Matt Damon talks Future Projects, Oscars and Directing His First Feature |url=http://www.collider.com/2010/02/27/matt-damon-talks-future-projects-oscars-and-directing-his-first-feature-info-on-the-coen-brothers-true-grit-the-rfk-project-with-gary-ross-clint-eastwoods-hereafter-liberace-contagion-more/|first=Steve |last=Weintraub |work=collider.com |date=2010-02-27 |accessdate=2010-03-05}}</ref>
=== Upcoming films === He will next work with frequent collaborator Steven Soderbergh on a project as the longtime [[Liberace]] love interest, Scott Thorsen, opposite [[Michael Douglas]] in an upcoming film centered on the pianist's life.<ref>{{cite web |title=Michael Douglas To Play Liberace |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20303839,00.html|first=Peter |last=Mikelbank |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |date=2009-09-15 |accessdate=2009-09-15}}</ref> He will also star in ''[[We Bought a Zoo]]'', and has been cast to play in ''[[Elysium_(film)|Elysium]]''.
== Producing career == Along with Affleck and producers [[Chris Moore (film producer)|Chris Moore]] and Sean Bailey, Damon founded the production company [http://www.liveplanet.com/index.asp LivePlanet], through which the four created the documentary series ''[[Project Greenlight]]'' to find and fund worthwhile film projects from novice filmmakers.<ref name="PPGreenlight">{{cite news|author=Zap2It.com|title='Greenlight' gets green light|publisher=''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]''|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1ZINAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YnADAAAAIBAJ&pg=5492,2982593&dq=matt+damon+project+green+light|date=August 12, 2002|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> The company produced and founded the short-lived mystery-hybrid series ''[[Push, Nevada]]'', among other projects. ''Project Greenlight'' was nominated for an Emmy for Outstanding Reality Program in 2002, 2004, and 2005.<ref name="TisCaliBio"/>
In March 2010, Damon and Affleck teamed up again to sign a first-look production deal with [[Warner Bros.]]<ref name="USAToday10">{{cite news|author=Donna Freydkin|title=Busy actor, father Matt Damon is in the 'Green Zone'|work=[[USA Today]]|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2010-03-11-Damon11_ST_N.htm|date=March 11, 2010|accessdate=March 14, 2010}}</ref>
== Humanitarian work == [[File:Matt Damon in Haiti 2009.jpg|thumb|left|Damon volunteering in Haiti as part of the [[United Nations Stabilization Mission in Haiti|United Nations Stabilization Mission]]]]
Damon was the founder of [[H2O Africa Foundation]], the charitable arm of the ''[[Running the Sahara]]'' expedition,<ref name="TisCaliBio"/><ref name="H20">{{cite news|last=DeCwikiel-Kane|first=Dawn|publisher=''[[News & Record (Greensboro)|Greensboro News & Record]]''|title=Charlie Engle's office: the great outdoors|url=http://www.news-record.com/content/2008/08/31/article/carlie_engles_office_the_great_outdoors|date=August 31, 2008|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> which merged with [[WaterPartners]] to create [[Water.org]] in July 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://water.org/2009/07/new-waterorg/ |title=Water.org Working Toward Global Access to Safe Water |publisher=Water.org |date=2009-07-14 |accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref> He, along with George Clooney, Brad Pitt, [[Don Cheadle]], and [[Jerry Weintraub]], is one of the founders of [[Not On Our Watch: The Mission to End Genocide in Darfur and Beyond|Not On Our Watch]], an organization that focuses global attention and resources to stop and prevent mass atrocities such as in [[Darfur conflict|Darfur]].<ref name="NOT">{{cite web|publisher=NotOurWatchProject.org|title=Not On Our Watch|url=http://notonourwatchproject.org/who_we_are|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> Damon supports the [[ONE Campaign]], which is aimed at fighting [[AIDS]] and [[poverty]] in [[Third World]] countries. He has appeared in their print and television advertising. Damon is also an ambassador for OneXOne, a non-profit foundation committed to supporting, preserving and improving the lives of children at home in Canada, the United States, and around the world.<ref name="OneXOne">{{cite news|author=[[The Canadian Press]]|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/print/CTVNews/20070914/damon_charity_070914/20070914/?hub=SpecialEvent2&subhub=PrintStory|title=T.O. benefit gala hosted by Matt Damon raises $1M|accessdate=April 5, 2009|date=September 17, 2007|publisher=CTV}}</ref> Damon is also a spokesperson for [[Feeding America]], the largest USA-focused hunger-relief organization, and a member of their Entertainment Council, participating in their [[Ad Council]] PSAs.
Damon is a board member of Tonic Mailstopper (formerly GreenDimes), a company that attempts to halt junk mail delivered to American homes each day.<ref name="Oprah">{{cite web|publisher=Oprah.com|title=It's Easy Being Green|url=http://www.oprah.com/slideshow/oprahshow/oprahshow1_ss_20070420/6|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> Appearing on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' on April 20, 2007, Damon promoted the organization's efforts to prevent the trees used for junk mail letters and envelopes from being chopped down. Damon stated: "For an estimated dime a day they can stop 70 percent of the junk mail that comes to your house. It's very simple, easy to do, great gift to give, I've actually signed up my entire family. It was a gift given to me this past holiday season and I was so impressed that I'm now on the board of the company."<ref name="MDGreenDimes">{{cite news|author=Aceshowbiz|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/entertainment/2007-04/23/content_857704.htm|title=Matt Damon goes green with GreenDimes.com|accessdate=April 5, 2009|date=April 23, 2007|publisher=''[[China Daily]]''}}</ref>
In 2011, the documentary which he narrated, ''American Teacher'', opened in New York prior to national screening.<ref name=Docu>{{cite news|last=Phillips|first=Anna M.|title=Film Examines the Challenging Economics Facing Teachers|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/24/nyregion/film-examines-the-challenging-economics-facing-teachers.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Film%20Examines&st=cse|accessdate=24 September 2011|newspaper=The New York Times|date=24 September 2011}}</ref>
== In the media == === Kimmel and Damon === Comedian [[Jimmy Kimmel]] at some point started stating near the end of his [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television show ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', "My apologies to Matt Damon; we ran out of time." The line is a gag lampooning instances where shows cannot feature their last guest due to time constraints. On September 12, 2006, after a segment highlighting the running gag and a lengthy introduction by Kimmel, Damon finally appeared on the show, only for Kimmel to apologetically cut his interview and head to credits, as Damon cursed him. This encounter was entirely planned by Kimmel and Damon.<ref name="USAW">{{cite news|last=Lynch|first=Lorrie|publisher=''[[USA Weekend]]''|title=Who's News|url=http://www.usaweekend.com/06_issues/061217/061217whosnews.html|accessdate=April 5, 2009}} {{dead link| date=June 2010 | bot=DASHBot}}</ref>
Kimmel's girlfriend at the time, comedian [[Sarah Silverman]] appeared on ''Jimmy Kimmel Live'' on January 31, 2008 and aired a clip where she is singing a song entitled "[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!#"I'm Fucking Ben Affleck"|I'm Fucking Matt Damon]]." Damon appeared in the song with Silverman.<ref name="PeopleSarahMatt">{{cite news|last=Jordan|first=Julie|title=Behind Matt Damon's Raunchy Payback to Jimmy Kimmel|publisher=''[[People (magazine)|People]]''|date=February 2, 2008|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20175789,00.html|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> Kimmel responded by airing his own music video in which he announced, through song, that he is "fucking [[Ben Affleck]]." The video aired on February 24, 2008, and featured Affleck along with a host of celebrities, including [[Don Cheadle]], [[Brad Pitt]], [[Cameron Diaz]], [[Harrison Ford]], and [[Robin Williams]].
Later on, Kimmel's sidekick, Guillermo, appeared in a spoof of ''[[The Bourne Ultimatum (film)|The Bourne Ultimatum]]'', which starred Damon. He was then chased down by Damon as he cursed about Kimmel being behind all this.
The most recent encounter was titled "The Handsome Men's Club" which featured Kimmel, along with other "Handsome Men" including [[Matthew McConaughey]], [[Rob Lowe]] and [[Lenny Kravitz]]. At the end of the skit Kimmel has a door slammed in his face by Damon stating that they had run out of time and then Damon continues with a sinister laugh.<ref name="NYTKimmelAffleck">{{cite news|last=Wyatt|first=Edward|title=Late-Night TV Satires Become Online Hits |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=February 27, 2008|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/27/arts/television/27kimm.html?_r=1&ref=arts&oref=slogin|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref>
=== Political views === Damon appeared on ''[[Hardball with Chris Matthews]]'' in December 2006 and, while discussing the ongoing [[war in Iraq]], he stated: "I don't think that it's fair, as I said before, that it seems like we have a fighting class in our country that's {{sic|hide=y|comprised |of}} people who have to go for either financial reasons, or ... if you're gonna send people to war, then that needs to be shared by everybody."<ref name="OYE">{{cite news|publisher=United Press International|title=Damon: Maybe Bush twins should go to Iraq|url=http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20061215-091251-2299r |date=December 15, 2006|accessdate=April 5, 2009 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070105010500/http://www.upi.com/NewsTrack/view.php?StoryID=20061215-091251-2299r |archivedate = January 5, 2007}}</ref>
On September 10, 2008, a video was released on [[YouTube]] by the ''[[Associated Press]]'' in which Damon criticized the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Vice Presidential candidate [[Sarah Palin]], whom he found unready to lead the country in case [[John McCain]] were to not make it through his first term. Damon referred to Palin as a "...bad [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] movie... 'I'm just a hockey mom from Alaska here to take on the White House,'" and added, "It's absurd ... I need to know if she really thinks [[dinosaur]]s were here [[Young Earth creationism|4,000 years ago]]. Because sheâs gonna have the [[Nuclear football|nuclear codes]]."<ref name="DamonPalin">{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/barackobama/3310993/YouTubes-best-US-election-videos.html|title=YouTube's best US election videos|publisher=[[Telegraph.co.uk]]|date=October 31, 2008|accessdate=April 5, 2009 | location=London}}</ref>
Damon narrated the audiobook version of historian [[Howard Zinn]]'s ''[[A People's History of the United States]]'', published in 2003.<ref name="DamonZinn">{{cite web|url= http://www.learnoutloud.com/Catalog/Politics/-/A-Peoples-History-of-the-United-States/190|title=Product page for the audio book|publisher=Learnoutloud.com|accessdate=October 9, 2009}}</ref> Zinn had been his next-door neighbor growing up in Cambridge.
== Personal life == [[File:Matt Damon 66Ã¨me Festival de Venise (Mostra) 16.jpg|alt=Damon in a tuxedo and bow-tie, with his wife wearing a low-cut, silver gown.| thumb|right|Damon with wife Luciana BozÃ¡n Barroso at the 2009 Venice International Film Festival]] Damon dated his ''Good Will Hunting'' co-star [[Minnie Driver]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.nytimes.com/1998/08/02/movies/film-when-the-character-calls-minnie-driver-listens.html?pagewanted=1|title=When the Character Calls, Minnie Driver Listens|publisher=The New York Times|date=August 2, 1998|accessdate=March 6, 2010 | first=Laura | last=Winters}}</ref> He later had a two-year relationship with actress [[Winona Ryder]].<ref name="People - Bio"/> From 2001 to 2003, he dated Odessa Whitmire, a former personal assistant of [[Billy Bob Thornton]] and Ben Affleck.<ref name="People - Bio"/> While filming ''[[Stuck on You (film)|Stuck on You]]'' in 2003,<ref name="meetingbarroso">{{cite news|last=Barlow|first=Helen|publisher=''The Sydney Morning herald''|title=Payday the thirteenth|url=|date=June 8, 2007|accessdate=February 22, 2010}}</ref> Damon met [[Argentina|Argentine]]-born Luciana BozÃ¡n Barroso (born 1976) in [[Miami]], where she was working as a [[bartender]].<ref name="USATBartender">{{cite news|author=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[USA Today]]''|title=Matt Damon, fiancee wed|url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2005-12-09-damon-wedding_x.htm|date=December 9, 2005|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> They married in a private [[civil ceremony]] on December 9, 2005, at the [[Manhattan Marriage Bureau]] near [[New York City Hall]].<ref name="USATBartender"/> Damon became stepfather to Barroso's young daughter, Alexia, from her previous marriage. The couple's first child together, daughter Isabella, was born on June 11, 2006.<ref name="EWIsabella">{{cite news|last=Greenblatt|first=Leah|publisher=''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''|title=Monitor|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1204719,00.html|date=June 16, 2006|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> On August 20, 2008, Barroso gave birth to the couple's second child, Gia Zavala Damon, both girls born in Miami, Florida.<ref name="GIABirth">{{cite news|author=[[Access Hollywood]] |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/26319534/wid/17621070/|title=Matt Damon and wife welcome daughter|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=August 20, 2008|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> On October 20, 2010, Barroso gave birth to their third daughter, Stella Zavala Damon, in New York.<ref name="STELLABirth">{{cite web|url=http://celebritybabies.people.com/2010/10/23/matt-damon-and-wife-welcome-daughter-stella/|title= Matt Damon and Wife Welcome Daughter Stella Zavala|work=People|date=October 23, 2010|accessdate=October 23, 2010}}</ref> As of 2011, Damon and his family reside in [[Manhattan]].<ref name="USAToday10"/>
Damon is a fan of the [[Boston Red Sox]].<ref name="MattRedSox">{{cite news|last=Edes|first=Gordon|title=Loyalty not an act for this Red Sox fan|publisher=''[[The Boston Globe]]''| date=November 27, 2007|url=http://www.boston.com/sports/baseball/redsox/articles/2007/11/27/loyalty_not_an_act_for_this_red_sox_fan/|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> After the team won the [[2007 World Series]], he narrated the commemorative DVD release of the event.<ref name="DamonBOSOXDVD">{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Doug|title=World Series DVD coming Nov. 27|publisher=[[MLB.com]]|date=November 9, 2007|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article_entertainment.jsp?ymd=20071109&content_id=2297512&vkey=entertainment&fext=.jsp|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref>
Damon enjoys playing poker and has competed in several [[World Series of Poker]] (WSOP) events<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/poker/2007-07-09-wsop-winnings_N.htm|title=Final table veterans conserve World Series winnings|accessdate=October 28. 2010|date=July 9, 2007|work=[[USA Today]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Ed|last=Koch|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/may/15/ups-downs-world-series-poker/|title=The highs and lows of the World Series of Poker|accessdate=October 28, 2010|date=May 15, 2008|work=[[Las Vegas Sun]]}}</ref> including the [[2010 World Series of Poker]] main event.<ref>{{cite news|first=Dan|last=Kadlec|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1997467,00.html|title=World Series of Poker: Attack of the Math Brats|accessdate=October 28, 2010|date=June 28, 2010|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]}}</ref> He dropped $25,000 at the WSOP while researching his role as a professional poker player in ''Rounders'' (1998)<ref>{{cite journal|title=Laugh Lines; Punch Lines|date=May 17, 1998|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|page=2}}</ref> and after filming the movie Damon was busted out of the 1998 WSOP by poker professional [[Doyle Brunson]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Andrew|last=Essex|author2=Tricia Laine|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,283314,00.html|title=Poker Faces|accessdate=October 28, 2010|date=May 22, 1998|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]}}</ref>
== Awards and honors == [[File:MattDamonHWoFOct10.jpg|alt=Pink granite star on a black granite side-walk.|thumb|Matt Damon's star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]]] {{main|List of awards and nominations received by Matt Damon}} * Damon won multiple awards for ''[[Good Will Hunting]]'', a film he co-wrote with [[Ben Affleck]]. He was nominated for the [[Academy Award]] as "Best Actor in a Leading Role" and won for "Best Writing, Screenplay Written Directly for the Screen".<ref name="Hartford9Nominations"/><ref name="WashPostWin"/> * On July 25, 2007, Damon became the 2,343rd person to receive a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Terri|last=Schwartz|url=http://hollywoodcrush.mtv.com/2009/12/11/the-evolution-of-matt-damon-follow-the-invictus-actors-career-in-photos/|title=The Evolution Of Matt Damon: Follow The 'Invictus' Actor's Career In Photos|accessdate=June 14, 2010|date=December 11, 2009|publisher=MTV}}</ref> He reacted to the award by stating: "A few times in my life I've had these experiences that are just kind of too big to process and this looks like it's going to be one of those times."<ref name="FoxNews">{{cite news|author=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Fox News Channel|Fox News]]|title=Matt Damon Gets Hollywood Walk of Fame Star|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290888,00.html|date=July 26, 2007|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> * Damon has been nominated for four [[Screen Actors Guild]] awards and seven [[MTV Movie Awards]] for various films. Additionally, he has three [[Emmy]] nominations for his work as producer on three seasons of ''[[Project Greenlight]]''.<ref name="IMDBAwards">{{cite web|publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]]|title=Awards for Matt Damon|url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0000354/awards|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> * Damon was named ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine's [[Sexiest Man Alive]] for 2007.<ref name="PeopleMagazine">{{cite news|publisher=''[[People (magazine)|People]]''|title=Matt Damon Named Sexiest Man Alive|url=http://www.people.com/people/package/gallery/0,,20154290_20159879,00.html|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> * Damon won 'Best Ass-Kicker' and 'Guy of the Year' at the [[Spike Guys' Choice Awards]] of 2008.<ref name="MediaRelease">{{cite web|publisher=PRNewswire.com|title=Spike TV Announces 2008 'Guys Choice Winners|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=104&STORY=/www/story/05-31-2008/0004823698&EDATE=|date=May 31, 2008|accessdate=April 5, 2009}}</ref> * On March 27, 2010, Damon received the 24th Annual [[American Cinematheque Award]], which was presented to him by Ben Affleck at a ceremony comprising roasts from Damon's colleagues and friends in the entertainment industry.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[American Cinematheque Award]] Official Website|title=The Presentation of the 24th Annual American Cinematheque Award|url=http://www.americancinematheque.com/ball/2010/2010_Matt_Damon.htm|date=March 27, 2010|accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref>
